title: Law and Sin
shortSummary: Romans Chapter 7 explores the believer’s relationship to the law and sin, illustrating the struggle between the desire to obey God’s law and the power of sin in the flesh. Paul uses the analogy of marriage to explain how Christians are released from the law through Christ and highlights the internal conflict that believers face until deliverance through Jesus Christ.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Epistle to the Romans during his third missionary journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and author of Romans, who explains the theological relationship between the law, sin, and the believer.

keyCharacters.name: The Woman
keyCharacters.description: Used as an illustrative example in the marriage analogy to explain the believer’s release from the law.

definitions.definition: The Mosaic Law given to Israel, which reveals sin but cannot save from sin.
Strong desire or lust, especially sinful desire, which sin uses to provoke disobedience.
Pertaining to the flesh or sinful nature, opposed to the spiritual nature.
The renewed life empowered by the Holy Spirit, enabling believers to serve God beyond the letter of the law.

outline.heading: The Law’s Dominion and the Marriage Analogy
outline.description: Paul explains that the law has authority over a person only as long as they live, using the example of a married woman bound to her husband until his death. Believers are 'dead to the law' through Christ’s body, freeing them to serve God and bear fruit.

outline.heading: The Law and Sin’s Relationship
outline.description: Paul describes how sin uses the law to provoke sinful desires, leading to death. Though the law is holy and good, sin exploits it to produce spiritual death, revealing the law’s role in exposing sin’s power.

outline.heading: The Inner Conflict of the Believer
outline.description: Paul candidly shares the struggle between his desire to obey God’s law and the sinful nature within him. He identifies two laws at war: the law of God in his mind and the law of sin in his flesh, resulting in spiritual captivity.

outline.heading: Thanksgiving for Deliverance through Christ
outline.description: Paul expresses anguish over the wretched condition caused by sin but thanks God for deliverance through Jesus Christ. He concludes with the believer’s dual service: serving God with the mind but struggling with sin in the flesh.

application: Recognize that the law reveals sin but cannot save; rely on Christ’s death and resurrection for true freedom.
Understand the ongoing spiritual battle within and seek God’s strength through prayer and the Holy Spirit to overcome sin.
Delight in God’s law inwardly, allowing it to guide your mind and heart even as you struggle against the flesh.
Give thanks regularly for deliverance through Jesus Christ, trusting in His power to sustain you in obedience.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore, my brethren, ye also are become dead to the law by the body of Christ; that ye should be married to another, even to him who is raised from the dead, that we should bring forth fruit unto God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse explains how believers are freed from the law through Christ’s death and resurrection, enabling a new life of fruitful service to God.

keyVerses.text: For we know that the law is spiritual: but I am carnal, sold under sin.
keyVerses.significance: Paul acknowledges the spiritual nature of the law contrasted with the believer’s struggle with the sinful flesh.

keyVerses.text: O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death? I thank God through Jesus Christ our Lord. So then with the mind I myself serve the law of God; but with the flesh the law of sin.
keyVerses.significance: These verses express the believer’s despair over sin’s power and the ultimate deliverance found only in Jesus Christ.
